ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.2_0: At that time two monks were traveling through the Kosalan country on their way to Sāvatthī.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.3_0: One of them wanders without misbehaving.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.4_0: The second monk said to him,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.6_0: Because of that the first monk became resentful.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.7_0: They then carried on to Sāvatthī.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.8_0: Just then an association in Sāvatthī was offering a meal to the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.9_0: When the second monk had finished his meal and refused an invitation to eat more,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.10_0: the resentful monk went to his own family and got some almsfood. He then went to the other monk.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.14_0: And because he was pressured, he ate the almsfood.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.15_0: The resentful monk then said to him,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.16_0: “Who are you to correct me when you eat food that’s not leftover even though you have finished your meal and refused an invitation to eat more?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.20_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Udāyī,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.21_0: “How can a monk invite a monk who has finished his meal and refused an invitation to eat more to eat food that’s not leftover?” ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.22_0: “Is it true, monk, that you did this?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.25_0: “... Foolish man, how can you do this?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.26_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...”...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.27_0: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.28.1_0: ‘If a monk invites a monk, whom he knows has finished his meal and refused an invitation to eat more, to eat staple or non-staple food that is not left over, saying, “Here, monk, eat,” aiming to criticize him, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.4_0: ...The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.8_0: whom has eaten any of the five staple foods, even just what fits on the tip of a blade of grass.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.9_0: Refuses an invitation to eat more:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.10_0: there is eating; there is staple food; it is offered by one standing within arm’s reach; there is a refusal.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.12_0: the making it leftover is done with food that is not allowable;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.13_0: it is done with food that has not been received;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.14_0: it is done with food that is not held in hand;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.15_0: it is done by one who is not within arm’s reach;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.16_0: it is done by one who has not finished his meal;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.17_0: it is done by one who has finished his meal, who has refused an invitation to eat more, but who has risen from his seat;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.19_0: it is leftover from one who is sick—
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.22_0: apart from the five staple foods, the post-midday tonics, the seven-day tonics, and the lifetime tonics—the rest is called “non-staple food”.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.24_0: there are five kinds of staple food: cooked grain, porridge, flour, fish, and meat.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.26_0: saying, “Take as much as you like.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.28_0: he knows by himself or others have told him or the donor has told him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.30_0: if he replies, “I’ll accuse him,” “I’ll accuse him,” “... I’ll remind them,” “... I’ll counter-accuse them,” “... I’ll counter-accuse them,” “... I’ll counter-remind them,” “... I’ll humiliate them,” he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.31_0: If, because of what he says, the other monk receives it with the intention of eating it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.32_0: For every mouthful, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.33_0: When the other monk has finished eating, he commits an offense entailing confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.2.1_0: If the other monk has refused an invitation to eat more, and he perceives that he has, and he invites him to eat staple or non-staple food which is not leftover, he commits an offense entailing confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.2.2_0: If the other monk has refused an invitation to eat more, but he is unsure of it, and he invites him to eat staple or non-staple food which is not leftover, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.2.3_0: If the other monk has refused an invitation to eat more, but he does not perceive that he has, and he invites him to eat staple or non-staple food which is not leftover, there is no offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.2.4_0: If he invites him to eat post-midday tonics, seven-day tonics, or lifetime tonics for the purpose of food, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.2.5_0: If, because of what he says, the other monk receives it with the intention of eating it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.2.6_0: For every mouthful, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.2.7_0: If the other monk has not refused an invitation to eat more, but he perceives that he has, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.2.8_0: If the other monk has not refused an invitation to eat more, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.2.9_0: If the other monk has not refused an invitation to eat more, and he does not perceive that he has, there is no offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.3.1_0: there is no offense for him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.3.2_0: if she gives it after having it made leftover;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.3.3_0: if he gives it, saying, “Have it made leftover and then eat it;”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.3.4_0: if he gives it, saying, “Take this food for the benefit of someone else;”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.3.5_0: if he gives the leftovers from a sick person;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.3.6_0: “When there’s a reason, if there’s a reason, make use of these;”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.3.8_0: if he is the first offender.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.3.9_0: The sixth rule, the second training rule on invitation, is finished.
